d16afa0ae7c.description: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales. Part of WIRED Media Group.
d16afa0ae7c.name: Backchannel
d16afa0ae7c.shortDescription: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales.

paragraphs.text: But this time, no one should be laughing it off. Instead of a ploy to distract, Amazon has been plugging away at a vision that portends a bigger role for drones in our life than we once thought. Oh my god!
paragraphs.name: 09d5

paragraphs.text: Amazon’s drones are built to go fast — the speeds are 60 miles an hour and beyond. They fly at altitudes between 200 and 400 feet, well under the 500 feet where general aviation vehicles fly. A sortie can go as far as 20 miles roundtrip, from warehouse to customer and back. (That’s known as an “ABA mission.”) When it reaches the GPS coordinates of its destination, it looks for a unique “marker” — an electronically identifiable welcome-mat that the customer sets out in a good landing place — and drops off the package. (The package can be up to five pounds or so, which covers around 85 to 90 percent of Amazon deliveries.) When the drone returns to base, the battery is swapped out and the flying courier is ready for another run.
paragraphs.name: b4cc
66bd
paragraphs.text: All of this is done without human intervention. Drones know where to go and how to get there without a human sitting at a ground station actually flying the plane. Communication takes place by signals — an Air Prime technician can order a drone to land — but ultimately the drones are autonomous. Amazon envisions that eventually it will have sort of an air traffic controller monitoring the flight patterns of multiple drones.

92eb53f6e7c0.title: It’d be great to see journalists, researchers, or even Amazon itself look into the power…

paragraphs.text: It’d be great to see journalists, researchers, or even Amazon itself look into the power implications of a widespread implementation. Presumably some petrol is saved by having less truck deliveries, but drones run on electricity and Amazon doesn’t have a stellar history of sourcing power from non-polluting power sources.
paragraphs.name: a350

3733f531e8.title: I’m having visions of Doctor Who and Torchwood. This is very cool but kinda scary.

paragraphs.text: I’m having visions of Doctor Who and Torchwood. This is very cool but kinda scary.

7c6e921e15a6.title: Expect drones to be restricted to virtual pathways in the air as the result of a settlement in…

paragraphs.text: Expect drones to be restricted to virtual pathways in the air as the result of a settlement in coming class-action lawsuits by annoyed homeowners.
paragraphs.name: 9ba6

paragraphs.text: Home delivery will be scrapped in favor of secure pick-up points.

16d9c4c3ac4.title: Ground delivery, not air delivery. Robots. not drones.

paragraphs.text: Ground delivery, not air delivery. Robots. not drones.

The reason drones seem like a publicity stunt is cause they are. They cannot service most of the 80% of North Americans that live in urban centers. Instead lets talk robots that are capable of navigating sidewalks (or bike lanes!) to make deliveries… like Dominos DRU…

paragraphs.text: Hopefully they’re also working on the noise these things make. The buzzing of drones is bound to cause some locals to detest them.

paragraphs.text: With their partner UPS — they already have delivered a commercial package launched from one of their UPS electric delivery vehicles.

29f2a418be1d.title: Why can these not charge in transit or use a hive/node model to continuously be ready to deliver?

paragraphs.text: Why can these not charge in transit or use a hive/node model to continuously be ready to deliver? This is in use here in Australia across agricultural drones implementation, increasing the flight time and reducing the down time of the drone.
paragraphs.name: 7e54

2bdc1aa44e2e.title: Oh, I cant wait to see those little guys zooming around the sky!

paragraphs.text: Oh, I cant wait to see those little guys zooming around the sky!

1fc373543403.title: Will drone delivery lower the cost of shipping?

paragraphs.text: Will drone delivery lower the cost of shipping? That’s my question. Yes, taking the human element, not to mention fuel costs, out of the labor equation is certainly an attractive idea. And widespread use will certainly lower the carbon footprint somewhat. But then FAA regulations (already in place with recreational drones — you need to register them…

5214ce587275.title: I’m excited by these developments, and gobsmacked by the objections raised in the comments.

paragraphs.text: I’m excited by these developments, and gobsmacked by the objections raised in the comments. I wonder what kind of concerns were raised at the beginning of the Industrial Revolution? “Too noisy, too fast, too polluting. All this change, I’m scared!” Change happened anyway.
paragraphs.name: c92c

paragraphs.text: Another job killed by Amazon. Maybe flying over rural areas where people can shoot them out of the sky or just hack the code and have all packages directed to land on their landing pad would stop this nonsense. How many birds have died trying to avoid a drone? Bezos make think it’s cool but this seems like a fool’s errand. How many Uber drivers does…
paragraphs.name: 8c49

paragraphs.text: Michael Craig nailed it. This gee-whiz Jetsons fantasy is ridiculous, just like it was in the 1960s. There’s a reason the flying cars we fantasized about as kids were never developed for the consumer market. Oh the carnage!

3d4be9fb003f.title: If you take this a few steps further, I think you get to some really interesting places.

paragraphs.text: If you take this a few steps further, I think you get to some really interesting places. Flying anti-G cars, the Cold War, the Napoleonic Code, Bismarck realpolitik, the dot com bust- you can’t predict the future. Evolution happens, genetically, culturally, electronicly, when there are really quick changes in a disruptive environment or really slowly…
paragraphs.name: 2cd6

virtuals.subtitle: So imagine Flynn flips, Trump is dumped, we are years into a new benevolent world order. Still no flying cars, no manned mission to Mars…

content.subtitle: So imagine Flynn flips, Trump is dumped, we are years into a new benevolent world order. Still no flying cars, no manned mission to Mars…

4b8f813ab68d.title: I knew he was serious when he mentioned it YEARS ago but no one could conceive of how.

paragraphs.text: I knew he was serious when he mentioned it YEARS ago but no one could conceive of how. I think it’s fascinating “brave new world” that will wind up costing a bit BUT may just cut out the expense of having to reimburse for damages during shipping. (I’m an Amazon seller and this has been my grouse so I know from personal experience)
We’ll see how this plays out in the next 2–3 years
paragraphs.name: 14bf

ad328a640f16.title: Besides Amazon, UPS is dead serious about using drones as well.

paragraphs.text: Besides Amazon, UPS is dead serious about using drones as well. The implication is much larger in the latter case as while Amazon delivers its own packages, UPS delivers for just about everybody else. I saw a Youtube video of a UPS truck with human driver stopping on the highway. The driver then retracted the truck’s roof so that a drone could lift…
paragraphs.name: aba7

b50afeefca86.title: Collision avoidance and reliable navigation will need to be near-perfect to avoid political…

paragraphs.text: Collision avoidance and reliable navigation will need to be near-perfect to avoid political backlash. Outfitting drones (and even homes and other fixed infrastructure) with next-gen real-time sensing tech will help. http://bit.ly/1J3BlEf
